awd_titl_txt: Disparate Pathways to Working Longer, Retiring, or Other Exits
awd_abstract_narration:
Baby boomers, born 1946-64, are moving to and through the conventional retirement years in unprecedented numbers, even as conventional retirement protections and expectations are unraveling. Existing studies of earlier cohorts of retirees do not fully capture the timing, sequencing, and voluntariness of short-term work-hour and workforce paths and transitions that Boomer men and women may experience. This project examines the experiences of women and men in their 50s, 60s, and 70s as they navigate later adulthood. The project assesses who is working longer, as well as the timing of exits from and reentries into employment. The project also examines whether these dynamics vary between advantaged and disadvantaged workers.  The project will assess whether working longer matters for the financial sustainability of individuals and their families, or the extent to which age-graded safety nets are effective.  Scientific advances from this work will inform the development of policy interventions promoting possibilities for working longer as well as for unpaid community engagement. These insights are key in light of the extraordinary numbers of Boomer women and men considering or undergoing labor market transitions moving them from social inclusion to social exclusion from the mainstream of society.

This project charts patterned short-term workforce constellations, capturing similarities and differences in sequencing and timing, for over 850,000 women and men ages 50 to 75 over eight time points. The project draws on linked Current Population Survey (CPS) monthly panel data from 1998 to 2018, with subsequent use of data from 2020. Individuals are surveyed in the CPS over a period of up to 16 months, which permits study of labor force entry and exists during that time frame.  Using sequence and multi-level analysis, the  project identifies the impacts of inequalities in patterned workforce constellations by social location, including variations by age, gender, education, race/ethnicity, and nativity, in combination with geosocial locations. The project will capture the contemporary complexity, heterogeneity, and inequities in short-term 16-month work-hour/workforce and family living arrangement dynamics of Boomer women, men, and couples, examining similarities and differences in the experiences of Boomers and the cohort preceding them. The project will assess the predictive effects of resources such as prior health, income, and job tenure, combined with disadvantaged social statuses and geographical locations, on the likelihood of following particular workforce patterns, and whether these predictive effects differ by cohort and time period. The project will assess the relationship of patterned short-term work constellations to continuity and change in income levels, civic engagement, and shifting family living arrangements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
This study aims to promote understanding of the changing later work course in terms of the pathways older Americans are taking to their final exit from the workforce (typically retirement) and how they spend their time in this transitional life phase. In doing so, we demonstrate inequalities in the ways women and men with different levels of education and with different race/ethnicities make the journey to retirement.  When COVID-19 erupted, we investigated its different impacts, finding inequities by race, gender, and age in older Americans’ work attachments as well as those in midlife and among young people just launching their work careers.  Our findings have considerable intellectual merit in revealing the multiple – and inequitable – pathways to retirement and other exits, and the ways they play out in the timing of such exits and time use. There is also considerable intellectual merit in showing the frequency of short-term employment changes among Americans in their 50s, 60s, and early 70s. This study also has broader societal impacts – showing the outdatedness of deeply embedded temporal policies and practices presuming many decades of full-time employment to be followed lock-step by one-way, one-time, irreversible retirement exits. Existing policies and practices were designed for (mostly male) workers in single-provider/homemaker households in the middle of the last century, no longer fitting the reality of an older workforce increasingly composed of two-earner households, caregivers of ailing family members, older workers desiring to work less or with health conditions, and those seeking “encore” jobs after leaving their career jobs. Global labor markets, economic dislocations, and technological advances are transforming the experiences of older workers and retirees in the face of an aging population and workforce. In the face of these tumultuous times, there is no longer a lock-step path to and through retirement, and yet antiquated clockworks of work and retirement remain fundamental arrangements structuring the human experience of older workers and their family members. Our evidence calls not only for new ways of working but also for institutionalizing alternative working paths for those approaching or moving through the conventional retirement years.

 


Last Modified: 07/28/2023
Modified by: Phyllis E Moen
